## üß≠ What We Do

Our work is organized around three main pillars:

### Pillar 1: Spatial Analysis

We apply a geographic lens to pressing policy questions on poverty and inequality. Whether it's identifying where jobs are (and aren't) for the poor, mapping urban deprivation, or analyzing rural income dynamics, we use spatially disaggregated data to generate actionable insights. This includes household surveys, censuses, administrative records, private sector data, and satellite-based remote sensing ‚Äî covering everything from climate and land use to infrastructure and conflict. We also develop and share open, reproducible code and tools that can be adapted across countries and topics.

[Learn more about our Spatial Analysis work ‚Üí](projects/spatial-analysis.qmd)

### Pillar 2: Knowledge and Data Center

We bring clarity to the what, why, and how of using geospatial data in poverty analysis. This pillar focuses on:

- Building a curated repository of geospatial data sources and methods, with clear guidance on how they can (and can't) be used in applied work.
- Showcasing examples of microeconomic analyses that successfully integrate geospatial data to answer real-world policy questions.

[Explore our Knowledge and Data Center ‚Üí](projects/knowledge-data-center.qmd)

### Pillar 3: Capacity Building

We help demystify geospatial data for microeconomists. Through hands-on trainings and peer-learning events, we build core skills for microeconomists to use geospatial methods with confidence. Whether you're just getting started or looking to refine your toolkit, we're here to support you through our growing Community of Practice.

[Explore our seminars and training events ‚Üí](seminars/index.qmd)
